data.text:
The Nobel prize in literature (it’s a mistake to call it “for literature”) has walked hand in hand with controversy ever since the first winner was announced in 1901. Presenting the medal that year to the obscure Frenchphilosopher and poet Sully Prudhomme, Nobel chairman Carl Wirsen talked proudly of the writer’s “cosmopolitan aspirations” and “idealistic tendency”. Forty-two Swedish authors and artists disagreed, and wrote an open letter denouncing the choice and proposing Leo Tolstoy instead.
